note.body:
I've tried replace GdkPixbuf with GdkTexture, but failed, due to missing the follow apis:
```
gdk_pixbuf_scale_simple
gdk_cairo_set_source_pixbuf

gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_size
gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_scale
```

GdkTexture is the replacement for GdkPixbuf, for compatibility and convenient，keep the talent with GdkTexture looks good:
```
// Existed apis
gdk_pixbuf_new_subpixbuf 
gdk_pixbuf_scale_simple
gdk_pixbuf_rotate_simple

// New apis
gdk_texture_new_subtexture
gdk_texture_scale_simple
gdk_texture_rotate_simple
```

> > GdkPixbufPixbufAnimation
> >
> Nobody uses that, people use video. And GtkMediaFile exists for that.

My app use the `GdkPixbufPixbufAnimation` to show the animation image

Please avoid just mentioning API that is supposedly needed. We need to know the use case instead to know if and what API makes sense.

Glycin for example supports animated GIF and WebP, as well as APNG (see [glycin README](https://gitlab.gnome.org/sophie-h/glycin#supported-image-formats)) but the `GdkPixbufPixbufAnimation` API is just not good, so no reason to copy that.

> `gdk_pixbuf_new_subpixbuf`

Depending on use case:

* `gtk_snapshot_push_clip()` and the original texture
* `GtkSnapshot` + `gsk_renderer_render_texture()` like above
* `g_bytes_new_from_bytes()` for the subpart + `GdkMemoryTexture`

> `gdk_pixbuf_scale_simple` / `gdk_pixbuf_rotate_simple`

Needs using `GtkSnapshot` + `gsk_renderer_render_texture()` , see above

> `GdkPixbufPixbufAnimation`

Nobody uses that, people use video. And `GtkMediaFile` exists for that.

> `gdk_cairo_set_source_pixbuf`

If you need to use Cairo, don't use `GdkTexture` or `GdkPixbuf`, use `cairo_surface_t`. You can use [gdk_texture_download()](https://docs.gtk.org/gdk4/method.Texture.download.html) for that, the docs even have an example for downloading into a cairo surface.

I think these functions should have replacements too
```
gdk_pixbuf_new_subpixbuf --> ??? / gdk_texture_new_subpixbuf 
gdk_pixbuf_scale_simple --> ??? / gdk_texture_scale_simple
gdk_pixbuf_rotate_simple --> ??? / gdk_texture_rotate_simple

GdkPixbufPixbufAnimation --> ????

gdk_cairo_set_source_pixbuf --> gdk_cairo_set_source_texture
```

target_title: Switch to the new ci-based release process

note.body: Merged, updated the description.

target_title: Switch to the new ci-based release process

note.body:
Applications can trivially implement this with almost no extra changes needed once we merge https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/citemplates/-/merge_requests/56

Libraries on the other hand will be required to have a CI job that does meson dist already. I am working on a template that uses gnome-build-meta and buildstream that will do that and we can drop in place for any module in gnome-core that doesn't have one already, but it won't be ready this week most likely.

target_title: Switch to the new ci-based release process

note.body: Yeah, we should replace it with a link to the handbook, once it is merged.

target_title: Switch to the new ci-based release process

note.body: :information_source: The link to the WIP handbook page will get outdated as iterations happen in the merge request, since it points at a specific pipeline artifact. There is no way to point at the latest version as far as I know. I updated the link to the current version, and added a link to the merge request.

target_title: Switch to the new ci-based release process

note.body:
The point of thumbnails is to do the big work (scaling from huge image to thumbnail) only once, and then repeatedly do the little work (load thumbnail png into a texture).

Not sure if that qualifies as an awful design.

And it is not very relevant to the topic of this initiative anyway.

and then create yet another glycin loader (which as mentioned aren't the fastest things in the world to instantiate) and load the png bytes into it to use the mentioned save feature (which i assume would only convert between formats in this scenario)?! that would be awful design

> regardless scaling would still be a necessary idea if we want a glycin thumbnailer (?)

```
snapshot = Gtk.Snapshot()
snapshot.add_texture(texture, 0, 0, 128, 128)
node = snapshot.to_node()
thumbnail = renderer.render_texture(node)
```

No idea what's causing that as I have no clue what's going on in details there, but it might be the age-old lod bias question where some people prefer the grainy look of higher bias and some the more smoothed out look of lower bias.  
The wood planks for example look straighter when smoothed, in particular those near a 45degree angle, while horizontal/vertical lines like the windows look clearer when not smoothed.

I'm sure things could be improved but IMO this is at a level of detail where "look at this screenshot" is not good enough anymore and I'd expect people to discuss details of the algorithms used.  
But that's belong in a GTK issue, not here.

(Also, I'm looking at this on a 200% screen so Firefox scales all the images up which blurs them anyway and I have to copy/paste them into Gimp and zoom in to even see those differences. Linear and nearest I can see, but these differences are really small.)

i did end up finding a relevant issue https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/-/issues/5980 so perhaps it is solvable (tho i still think that issue is relevant to this issue as pixbuf is very widely used as a workaround for it)

regardless scaling would still be a necessary idea if we want a glycin thumbnailer (?)

a regular texture node looks the same as trilinear scaling for me. i think they're just tiny screenshots. see this larger example of a regular node vs the same but the texture was scaled down 2x with pixbuf beforehand

![image](/uploads/005e7d2bc9ed6e5dac481b6c7b793c3c/image.png)

![image](/uploads/4fa1b9537c1537105302608445ef8fc5/image.png)

Did you just try a regular texture node?  
Because that all looks blurry, like someone forced a 100% image on a 150% screen.

> July 2022

here's some screenshots from the latest master gnome flatpak runtime 👍

linear scaling is pixelated

![image](/uploads/df5a652c8ae8f530f68079615ba5e7af/image.png)

nearest scaling is even more pixelated

![image](/uploads/b089455cbe2b7e60c3f0b2f50da774ba/image.png)

trilinear scaling is blurry (not as visible here, but at higher sizes it's a mess)

![image](/uploads/edb2d4a01129b6453b34fc1279f127c7/image.png)

pixbuf.from_stream_at_scale looks correct

![image](/uploads/d756978ab0162305fb492e66663129ed/image.png)

so gtk chose to have ugly image downscaling before and after these new renderers, that makes it seem even less like a bug even if you're right that i have no idea why it is done this way

> i assume it is intended behavior, it's meant to be fast,

Modern desktop GPUs are so incredibly fast, GTK cannot make them even break a sweat. I have a rendering benchmark that runs with 2000fps on a 4k screen - because it is limited by the CPU.

If you do any rendering on the CPU, you're doing it wrong. And that includes generating thumbnails.

The only reason stuff happens on the CPU is because nobody has written the GPU code yet.

> gtk's gpu downscaling is really ugly, as seen here https://gitlab.gnome.org/World/podcasts/-/merge_requests/222#note_1515318

That's a comment/screenshot from July 2022, probably on GTK 4.6, maybe 4.7. That was long before the new renderers happened.

i assume it is intended behavior, it's meant to be fast, it is the job of thumbnailers to do scaling. actually i'm not sure how the aforementioned glycin thumbnailer is meant to be written without a scale function perhaps i'm misunderstanding the post
Sounds like this should be a report over at gtk?

> [`gdk_pixbuf_scale`](https://docs.gtk.org/gdk-pixbuf/method.Pixbuf.scale.html)
> * Can be done via GTK Snapshot

i would appreciate a scale feature because gtk's gpu downscaling is really ugly, as seen here https://gitlab.gnome.org/World/podcasts/-/merge_requests/222#note_1515318
therefore scaling to multiple resolutions is necessary to create thumbnails in gtk apps. podcasts uses the rust image loading library but for example gapless which is written in vala relies on pixbuf's scale feature

> [`gdk_pixbuf_composite`](https://docs.gtk.org/gdk-pixbuf/method.Pixbuf.composite.html)

> * What is that? Does anyone need it?

That's basically the equivalent of doing

```
snapshot_translate (dest_x, dest_y);
snapshot.push_clip (0, 0, dest_width, dest_height);
snapshot.scale (scale_x, scale_y);
snapshot.append_texture (src, -offset_x, -offset_y, src.width(), src.height());
```

I believe it was used for things like drawing emblems onto icons.

> GTK can't drop its GdkPixbuf dependency until 5.0, since it is exposed in the API. A goal of this initiative should be to port applications away from gdk_texture_new_for_pixbuf, gtk_image_new_from_pixbuf and gtk_picture_new_for_pixbuf.

The most important part for applications is to stop using `GdkPixbuf` internally and use `GdkTexture` instead. nautilus!1659 has a bunch of discussions about issues with that inside Nautilus (that probably translate to other apps, particularly older ones).

I should also point out that `gdk_texture_new_for_pixbuf()` is the best API to use if applications want to drive this transition. Basically:

1. Replace some usage of `GdkPixbuf` with `GdkTexture` by using `gdk_texture_new_for_pixbuf()` and then using existing texture APIs.

2. Repeat step 1 repeatedly inside the codebase until as much as possible has been replaced.

3. Switch to using glycin for image loading.

4. In particular, review `gdk_texture_new...()` function usage and replace them with glycin for untrusted images (ie users' files or data sent from the internet or other processes).

target_title: Provide input purpose/content hints in text input entries

note.body: gnome-text-editor hints https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-text-editor/-/merge_requests/132 so OSKs have an idea to enable it. Hope that's the right way to do it with the current set of hints. Chatty does the same.

Should there be a dedicated initiative to document and advocate for apps (within, around and outside of GNOME) to use the new portal-based filechooser (in our case, Nautilus) available in GNOME 47, or should this be done as part of this existing initiative (if so, could someone add some new section above with the relevant information to point app developers to, a bit like what was done for the dark theme preference initiative)?

The following core components are not ported to gtk4 yet, and missing from the list:
- dconf-editor (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/dconf-editor/-/issues/65 | https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/dconf-editor/-/merge_requests/44)
- gdm (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gdm/-/issues/947)
- gnome-autoar (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-autoar/-/issues/52)
- gnome-color-manager
- gnome-session (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-session/-/issues/131)
- gnome-settings daemon (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-settings-daemon/-/issues/827)
- orca
- rygel
- xdg-user-dirs-gtk (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/xdg-user-dirs-gtk/-/issues/6 | https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/xdg-user-dirs-gtk/-/merge_requests/13)
